lg.l: THE Life of MAN to represent,Y03-P11@ 2 And turn it all to Ridicule,Y03-P11@ 3 Wit did a Puppet-show invent,Y03-P11@ 4 Where the Chief Actor is a Fool.Y03-P11@ 5 II.
The Gods of Old were Logs of Wood,Y03-P11@ 6 And Worship was to Puppets paid,Y03-P11@ 7 In Antick Dress the Idol stood,Y03-P11@ 8 And Priests and People bow'd the Head.Y03-P11@ 9 III.
No wonder then if ART began,Y03-P11@ 10 The simple Votaries to frame,Y03-P11@ 11 To Shape in Timber foolish Man,Y03-P11@ 12 And consecrate the Block to Fame.Y03-P11@ 13 IV.
From hence Poetick Fancy learn'd, Y03-P11@ 14 That Trees might rise from Human Forms,Y03-P11@ 15 The Body to a Trunk be turn'd,Y03-P11@ 16 And Branches issue from the Arms.Y03-P11@ 17 V.
Thus Daedalus and Ovid too,Y03-P11@ 18 That Man's a Blockhead have confest,Y03-P11@ 19 Powel and Stretch the Hint pursue,Y03-P11@ 20 Life is a Farce, the World a Jest.Y03-P11@ 21 VI.
The same great Truth South-Sea has prov'dY03-P11@ 22 On that fam'd Theatre, the Ally,Y03-P11@ 23 Where Thousands by Directors mov'dY03-P11@ 24 Are now sad Monuments of Folly.Y03-P11@ 25 VII.
What Momus was of old to JoveY03-P11@ 26 The same a Harlequin is now,Y03-P11@ 27 The Former was Buffoon aboveY03-P11@ 28 The Latter is a Punch below,Y03-P11@ 29 VIII.
This Fleeting-Scene is but a Stage, Y03-P11@ 30 Where various Images appear,Y03-P11@ 31 In different Parts of Youth and AgeY03-P11@ 32 Alike the Prince and Peasant share.Y03-P11@ 33 IX.
Some draw our Eyes by being Great, Y03-P11@ 34 False Pomp conceals mere Wood within,Y03-P11@ 35 And Legislators rang'd in StateY03-P11@ 36 Are oft but Wisdom in Machine.Y03-P11@ 37 X.
A Stock may chance to wear a Crown, Y03-P11@ 38 And Timber as a Lord take Place,Y03-P11@ 39 A Statue may put on a FrownY03-P11@ 40 And cheat us with a thinking Face.Y03-P11@ 41 XI.
Others are blindly led away, Y03-P11@ 42 And made to act for Ends unknown,Y03-P11@ 43 By the mere Spring of Wires they playY03-P11@ 44 And speak in Language not their own.Y03-P11@ 45 XII.
Too oft, alas! a Scolding Wife Y03-P11@ 46 Usurps a Jolly Fellow's Throne,Y03-P11@ 47 And many drink the Cup of Life,Y03-P11@ 48 Mix't and Embitter'd by a JOAN.Y03-P11@ 49 XIII.
In short, whatever Men pursue Y03-P11@ 50 Of Pleasure, Folly, War, or Love:Y03-P11@ 51 This Mimick-Race brings all to View,Y03-P11@ 52 Alike they dress, they talk, they move.Y03-P11@ 53 XIV.
Go on, Great Stretch, with Artful Hand,Y03-P11@ 54 Mortals to please and to deride,Y03-P11@ 55 And when Death breaks thy Vital Band,Y03-P11@ 56 Thou shalt put on a Puppet's Pride.Y03-P11@ 57 XV.
Thou shalt in Puny Wood be shewn, Y03-P11@ 58 Thy Image shall preserve thy Fame,Y03-P11@ 59 Ages to come thy Worth shall own,Y03-P11@ 60 Point at thy Limbs, and tell thy Name.Y03-P11@ 61 XVI.
Tell TOM he draws a Farce in vain,Y03-P11@ 62 Before he looks in Nature's Glass,Y03-P11@ 63 Puns cannot form a Witty Scene,Y03-P11@ 64 Nor Pedantry for Humour pass.Y03-P11@ 65 XVII.
To make Men act as Senseless Wood, Y03-P11@ 66 And chatter in a Mystick Strain,Y03-P11@ 67 Is a mere Force on Flesh and Blood,Y03-P11@ 68 And shews some Error in the Brain.Y03-P11@ 69 XVIII.
He that wou'd thus refine on THEE, Y03-P11@ 70 And turn thy Stage into a School,Y03-P11@ 71 The jest of Punch will ever be,Y03-P11@ 72 And Stand confest the greater FOOL.Y03-P11@
